reviewText: Have room for one more unoriginal story? A remake of the 2007 Israeli film of the same name, The Debt at least does a good job of adapting the original for a new audience. Flashing back and forth between two eras, The Debt tells the story of three Mossad agents who, in 1966, undertook a mission that made them national heroes... But did they really complete their mission, or is there more to the story? Three decades later, having enjoyed a life of some notoriety, the agents must decide whether or not to follow up on their original task, and as more details are revealed, the path becomes more treacherous for all involved. Though the shifts in time may be a little problematic for some at first, I found much to like in The Debt's smartly executed script and impressive acting. With stars like Tom Wilkinson, Helen Mirren, Jessica Chastain, Sam Worthington, Ciaran Hinds, and Marton Csokas filling out the bill, you can be assured this is one thriller that will engage you from start to finish.

reviewText: Debts take time, even generations, to settle. What we owe friends and loved ones often carries more urgency than those we'd eagerly pay enemies.In John (not football coach) Madden's taut espionage thriller "The Debt," young Mossad agents Stephan (Marton Csokas), David ( Sam Worthington), and Rachel (an electrifying Jessica Chastain) felt they owed their families, countrymen, and the world the capture and trial of Nazi war criminal Dieter Vogel (an superb Jasod Christiansen), the near-demonic "Surgeon of Birkenau." Their meticulous plan falls apart,  but Rachel's brave and resilient act ends Vogel's life.At least they return with that story to their home country, becoming national heroes and inspiring Rachel's daughter's best-selling book on the event. It also became their near30-year secret until stunning news in 1997 draws out a now-retired Rachel (the always stunning Helen Mirren) as the only person to settle accounts not just for Vogel's victims but for her family. (Mirren sounds especially convincing telling her child's father, "I wanted to do something to make my daughter proud of me.") Their cohort, David, may have been owed the biggest debt:  Vogel taunted him and his race years after murdering his family, and David took the guilt of the trio's secret to his grave."The Debt's"  settings masterfully capture gray, decaying East Berlin under constant watch, tension, and cigarette smoke. Madden builds explosive action scenes from cramped, vulnerable backgrounds: the leaking apartment young Rachel cannot leave, the doctor's office where the Surgeon of Birkenau has her legs spread in stirrups.  The 1997 scenes serve as character development and don't quite measure until the film's jaw-dropping conclusion.  But Mirren's key scene getting needed information from an after-hours newsroom packs its share of humor and tension (sexual and otherwise)."The Debt" is a sturdy, grown-up spy, revenge film, with Chastain and Mirren  providing a femimist twist.  Their thoughtful, even athletic performances settle the imagination it takes to see both actresses as one character(especially when dealing with David as lover, then martyr).  In a dwindling summer film season of sequels, special effects, and over-the-top acting, "The Debt" pays the audience its best returns.
summary: Chastain, Mirren's Powerful Performances Provide Audience Payback in "The Debt"

reviewText: This is a fictional account based on factual components. The movie is the story of a group of Israeli agents who infiltrate East Berlin to capture a Nazi war criminal known as the Surgeon of Birkenau.  This character is based on the Dr. Joseph Mengele, the doctor at Auschwitz who conducted medical experiments on Jewish prisoners at the death camp.  He was also known as The Angel of Death.  The three spies, two men and one women, capture but fail to extract their prey from East Berlin.  The remainder of the movie is about the ensuing events and how the trio dealt with their failure, pragmatically, morally and emotionally.  I do not want to say too much to give away more than necessary.  The drama is gripping a times although there are events and attitudes that are at times not believable - for example the female's impulsive romantic involvement with one of her colleagues.  Also, the actor chosen to play the elder version of one of the two males was at times weak, and this weakness was exacerbated by the fact that he bore little to no resemblance to his younger self; in contrast, the older actor for the other male and the woman were plausible versions of their younger counterparts.  The movie does provide strong drama throughout and raises important questions about the value of life and the difficult choices one must make under trying circumstances, as well as the consequences of those choices.

reviewText: We often think of 1945 as the end of World War II, and the arrival of Allied troops into Berlin as the death-knell of Nazi-controlled Germany. However, some of the story continues, granted on a much smaller scale, such as the manhunts for people suspected of war crimes like Adolf Eichmann, and the recovery of stolen artwork and artifacts. Much of the atrocities at the hand of the Nazis before and during World War II still linger and affect people today, more than 65 years ago at this writing. "The Debt" is a partially fictitious story about how the events of the 1930's and 1940's still carries on today. The story which begins about 20 years after the war doesn't end until 1997.The film begins in 1997 with the publication of a book about three young Israelis 30 years earlier in the service of Mossad in the mid-1960's. The book has been written by the young daughter of one of the agents, the mother now in her 50s. Although this is supposed to be a joyous occasion, the mother appears ambivalent about the whole affair, which is one of the keys to understanding this film. Mossad is the Israeli equivalent of the CIA, and the three agents were engaged in a manhunt for Dr Vogel, the so-called "Surgeon of Birkenau", who tortured victims in medical experiments during the Nazi regime in Germany. Although Dr Vogel appears to be a fictional character, I would guess he is largely based on the real-life Dr Joseph Mengele, who engaged in horrible medical experiments at the death camps at the behest of the Third Reich. The three Mossad agents, Rachel Singer, Stephan Gold, and David Peretz, have vowed to kidnap Vogel whom they believe is practicing gynecology in East Berlin under communist occupation and extradite him to Israel to face trial, similar to the fate of Adolf Eichmann only a few years earlier. Vogel, if based on Mengele, would be in his mid-50's in 1965.The film then flashes back to 1965 when two of the three agents, Rachel and David, pass through "Check-Point Charlie", the crossing station separating East and West Berlin from 1961 until 1990. Now in East Berlin, they meet up with Gold to resolve to kidnap the doctor. Their mission has three components. They must verify their subject as being the Nazi doctor, they must figure out a way to kidnap him, and lastly, the three with their prisoner must escape back into West Berlin under the nose of East Berlin guards. During this time, people caught trying to escape to the West from the East could be either imprisoned or shot. Presumably, once in West Berlin, they will be met by other members of the Mossad who will take Vogel back to Israel and force him to stand trial for war crimes and murder.Interspersed between the events of 1965-1966 are the events of 31 years later in 1997. Two of the three original agents, Rachel Singer, played by Helen Mirren, and Stefan Gold, played by Tom Wilkinson, are finding that the past has caught up with them, and they must deal with the events of three decades earlier. Singer's daughter has written a book about these young agent's experiences in the 1960's, but as events unfold, it may turn out that not all the events as written are completely accurate.An outstanding and mesmerizing tale of suspense and political intrigue, one of the best I have seen in recent years. The three younger actors, Jessica Chastain, Marton Csokas, and Sam Worthington play the younger versions of the agents, are really at the heart of the film and deserve as much credit as their older counterparts. As a pure action-suspense thriller, it can't be beat. As a political statement about the horrors of the holocaust, its one of the most compelling I've seen in such an offering in quite a few years. Just be warned that this is not escapist's fair.
summary: Outstanding Political Thriller Regarding the Next Generation After the Holocaust

reviewText: The Debt is a spy-thriller that focuses more on character development than action.  The time is 1965.  Three Israeli Mossad agents are tasked with capturing the Nazi war criminal Dieter Vogel, also known as "the Surgeon of Birkenau," and bringing him from East Berlin to Israel to stand trial for atrocities committed against the Jewish people.  Things do not go as planned, however, and the agents must improvise.  The movie alternates between the mission in 1965 and the aftermath in 1997, when the three are now old and famous, but bear a terrible secret.  Will they tell the truth or continue to perpetuate a lie?The acting is strong (particularly Helen Mirren as old Rachel and Jessica Chastain as young Rachel), and the directing is tight, maintaining suspense till the end.  The blu-ray transfer is great--both audio and visuals are what one would expect from a recent release.  The bonus features include the typical director's commentary and making-of documentaries.Parental advisory: The Debt contains some language and violence, including discussions of Holocaust atrocities.  While there is no nudity, there is implied sex and three uncomfortable-to-watch gynecological examinations with reproduction-related dialogue.  This is not a movie for pre-teens.I recommend The Debt.  It does not have the flash of a Jason Bourne movie, but is more realistic.  The agents, while skilled and physically fit, are nevertheless flesh and blood people with emotions.  It is worth seeing.
summary: The Truth Will Set You Free

reviewText: I rented this last weekend and watched it once by myself and then again with DH. The acting was superb, especially Helen Mirren as the aging Rachel Singer, Jessica Chastain as her younger self, and—in a complex and brilliantly nuanced performance—Jesper Christensen as Dieter Vogel, "The Suregon of Birkenau." But I have to knock off a star for the weird casting.Martin Csokas and Tom Wilkinson are well enough matched in their respective roles as the young and older Stefan Gold, but I was so confused by the casting for the roles of David Peretz (Sam Worthington/Ciaran Hinds) that it took a while before I could follow what was going on. By the end of the movie, the relationships were more clear, but the stark difference in appearance between the two actors set off a cognitive struggle that caused me to miss a lot of other important details and nuances in my effort to keep straight just who was who. I think this one casting mistake is a major flaw of the movie, although the actors themselves did their best with what they were given.The casting problem aside, I really did like this movie, and more so the second time through it. You could have heard a pin drop when DH and I were watching it, so gripping was this tragedy of errors. But it's subtle in its pacing and effects, with the tension building internally and not as a result of lots of blow-em-up, bash-em-up, fire-em-up scenes. Someone wanting an Arnold Schwarzenegger or Sylvester Stallone action flick will most certainly be disappointed; but those seeking a sophisticated thriller that will keep them wondering long after the ending credits role will I think be captivated by it. If my rental had not already expired, I'd watch it yet again.

reviewText: Seeing Jessica Chastain in both The Help, and Tree of Life, made me decide to see The Debt.Director John Madden directed Shakespeare in Love which won 7 Academy Awards including, Best Actress for Gwyneth Paltrow, and Best Supporting Actress for Judi Dench. He also directed Prime Suspect 3 starring both Helen Mirren and Ciaran Hinds, who both star in The Debt; and Captain Corelli's Mandolin.The Debt parallels real events. Mossad agents abducted Eichmann in Argentina in 1961, tried him in Israel, and executed him. The notorious Dr Mengele, the butcher of Auschwitz fled to South America, narrowly escaping the Mossad in Argentina, fleeing to Paraguay, and then Brazil. Birkenau is known also as Auschwitz Birkenau. Twenty four surgeons experimented on human captives, often performing unnecessary surgical operations without anaesthetic.In 1965, a rookie Mossad agent played by Jessica Chastain, crosses Checkpoint Charlie and joins two male agents in East Berlin, to identify and kidnap the notorious surgeon of Birkenau, now a gynaecologist. She must pose as a patient, and subject herself to the cold probings of her intimate place by the butcher, and take close up photos without arousing suspicion.Photographs of his terrible deeds haunt her and fill her with apprehension and fear. Photographs of smiling babies adorn his waiting room wall. A man who once took life from the world, now charged with bringing life into the world.Her legs in stirrups, vulnerable, afraid, he probes her intimate space with his instrument, as he asks probing questions, about her unfamiliar accent, about her mother, about how she found him. It's tense and gripping. He gives her sex advice, and injections which will help her become pregnant. Meanwhile her desire grows for the sensitive agent, but David though attracted is closed off, and a romantic triangle develops. Will the doctors advice pay off?When the mission goes wrong, the three agents and their captive remain in the same house. He would rather escape than die, and rather die than face trial. He senses the weakness in the relationships of his captors, and in their psyches, and pushes them to their psychological limits. He says things you would not expect to hear in a movie. As tensions mount, the great psychodramatic moments of the movie unfold. It's strangely intimate. He pushes the mother button with Rachel, while she shaves him with a cutthroat razor, and tears stream down her porcelain cheeks. She goes to the bathroom to throw up. When David, the sensitive one replies to him, 'you are a monster,' you can see from his facial expression that he is getting off on it. He plays them off each other. She is with him but it's you she wants. He seems able to read her mind, to guess her real name, intuit her condition. Here the acting is simply amazing and totally absorbing.The doctor succeeds in his goal. They return to Israel, with an invented truth, and a heavy secret. Thirty years later that secret will force Rachel out of retirement, so the real truth can remain unknown.The Debt is part suspense, part thriller, part psychodrama, its parts stirred by three great acting performances.Jessica Chastain as the lead is incredible, with a face crafted by the cinematic gods, one of the best new talents I have seen. I was totally wowed by her performance.Jesper Christensen delivers an astounding performance as the doctor, perhaps I am supposed to feel shock and outrage, yet I found it gripping and strangely delicious to watch the psychological cat and mouse game between him and her.Helen Mirren, shows a harder edge as the older Rachel, always a gripping presence.I love movies with a heroic female protagonist. When plans go awry, she steps out of the shadows looking for a light, she ventures into the stirrups, and she fights. She feels the fear and does it anyway. She is an everywoman required to do dangerous things. Other movies with great female protagonists would be Black Book, and The Girl Who Played With Firemovies. I wish Hollywood would make make more movies like these. All these are European movies.If you're like me and like psycho dramatic thrillers. I think you will love it, and I hope this was helpful.

reviewText: THE DEBT is the current version  of HA HOV written by Ido Rubenblum and writer/director Assaf Bernstein: their story and screen play were the nidus for the current version whch was revised and written by Matthew Vaughn, Jane Goldman Porter and directed by John Madden.The film opens at a gala party in Israel where Rachel Brenner (Helen Mirren) is being honored again for her role in ending the life of the infamous 'surgeon of Birkenau' who during WW II did heinous experiments on human beings in the camps of Birkinau, including being responsible for the death of Rachel's mother. But news arrives that at all old folks home in the Ukraine that the surgeon is still alive. We learn that the now retired Mossad secret agents Rachel (Helen Mirren) and Stefan (Tom Wilkinson) about their former colleague David (Ciarán Hinds) nee an explanation. Flash back to 1966 when the trio of  three Mossad agents (Rachel - played at the young age by Jessica Chastain, Stephan Gold (Marton Csokas)and  David Peretz (Sam Worthington) were  sent to capture the surgeon (Jesper Christensen) and erroneously allowed him to escape and promised each other to keep their secret, told the papers that he committed suicide. Rachel, Stefan and David decide they must complete their broken mission and go to the Ukraine, fine the surgeon and kill him. Stephan and David are not up to the task, so it is left to Rachel to finish their mission. The suspenseful hunt and chase is how the mission is accomplished.The manner in which the film is set into motion is a seamless interchange of the years 1944 during the war and the black and white images of the concentration camps, and 1965 when the three young Mossad agents captured the surgeon (and their interaction with him before his escape) and the present when the now 60ish Rachel carries out her duty. It is chilling, rich in character development, and maintains a degree of tension that is almost unbearable at times. But the other aspect of this film that keeps it form being yet another memoir of the mistreatment of the Jews in WW II is the element of humanity in each of the three Mossad agents as they deal with their task and yet interact with the evil and warped surgeon. reviewText: Three young Israeli Mossad agents are sent to Germany in 1965 to capture a notorious Nazi war criminal, a doctor who viciously performed atrocious experiments upon Jewish prisoners, but something goes wrong and the Nazi escapes. The three decide to cover up the mistake and claim that they killed the man. Now, thirty years later a man has surfaced who claims that he is that doctor.The movie is based on a Hebrew book called Hachov. This title can be translated as "The Debt" or as "The Obligation." I think that the latter translation captures the dilemma of the three agents better. The retired agents take three approaches to their problem. One feels an obligation to take revenge for the murders that the doctor did to Jews and other Nazis did to members of his family. One focuses on the obligation of morality, what is right and wrong, despite the harm that what she considers right may do to others. The third focuses on the obligation to be practical, to do what makes sense, to consider the impact their behavior will have on family and country.

reviewText: The Debt is a thoughtful political thriller with a greater emphasis on character development and conflict than death-defying feats, and the spirit of the filmmaking of this historical tale (shuttling between the 1960s and the 1990s)is told with the type of messy inventiveness of feature film making of the 1970's more than the paint by number flicks that are basically a sequence of special effect coups that ooos and ahhhs contemporary audiences in feature film and TV films today. What makes The Debt different is that it succeeds at creating a story that is character and plot driven at the same time. That Aristotelean idea that 'character is fate' plays out on this remarkable celluloid canvas--most significantly among the actors portraying the three young versions of the Mossad Trio, Jessica Chastain, Sam Worthington, and Marton Csokas, thereby truly fulfilling the potential of narrative film to show character development, action, time and place juxtapositions, and subtle behavior at the same. Each agent is dedicated to bringing justice to his/her country, but each has a personal narrative and personality that makes them all convincingly vulnerable, albeit in different ways.  Their basic personalities evolve into the logical characters that we see over 30 years later in the 1997 sequences of the movie.Without revealing too much about this unpredicatable but plausible plot, I can say that most everything on the screen gets it "right." It seems to me ironic that a narrative that holds to the classic traditions of what makes a good tragedy/drama is a rarity, and that is characters that demonstrate personal imperfection, flaws, and vulnerabilities that exist evem within real life "special ops" members. A lot of action films nowadays would probably cast Achilles without a vulnerable heel (which basically destroys the point of the hero).The three Mossad operators given the task of bringing a Nazi war criminal to justice don't exude the confidence or invincibility of their implausible counterparts that audiences seem to thrive on--I expect for the value of escapism. Instead, the agents betray much inner conflict when having to make very difficult decisions. But that makes the action more riveting, not less.  For this reason, after watching the film, you're not as likely to feel you've just been on a fun roller coaster ride like your typical Harrison Ford or Tom Cruise vehicle--all visceral and quickly forgetable.The only trouble I had with the film is that the agents circa 1970 didn't much physically resemble the same characters some 30 years later. But that would have been a feat of casting not easily negotiated, so I would let the matter slide. It's a minor issue compared to the fact that popular audiences will 'let slide'the fact that what they are watching are one-dimensional cartoon figures that are on the side of "right," without acknowledging that even justice has consequences and is rarely neatly tied up and set to rest. The Debt is entertaining and edifying, and exploits the medium craftily in its acting, direction, dialogue, and design. What more could you ask for? And you don't even need 3-D glasses to watch it.
summary: Political thriller where character & choice trump 'special' effects

reviewText: THE DEBT is more of a psychological thriller than an action thriller. The action simply provides the bedrock for the psychodrama. THE DEBT is a remake of a 2007 Israeli film which was rather different.The acting in THE DEBT is excellent, particularly that of Jessica Chastain as the younger Rachel. Chastain is a talented actress who, though she has appeared in many films, has fortunately managed to avoid celebrity. Helen Mirren, who plays the older Rachel turns in her usual work of stellar caliber.It is 1965. Stefan, David and Rachel are Mossad agents tasked to capture the Mengele-esque "Surgeon of Birkenau," a Dr. Vogel, who is living inconspicuously in East Berlin, practicing gynecology twenty years after escaping justice for his war crimes of useless and horrifying medical experiments on Auschwitz inmates.They capture Dr. Vogel but when they attempt to sneak him "over the wall" into West Berlin things go badly awry, and so the three agents are forced to care for him while awaiting extraction. Realizing that his captors have become as much a set of prisoners as he himself, the wily Vogel (who is an unrepentant Nazi to the core) begins to torment them psychologically; eventually, he makes his escape.Recriminations fly back and forth. Finally, Stefan convinces David and Rachel to agree to the story that they killed Dr. Vogel while he was trying to escape. Eventually, they are extracted, and return to Israel as heroes, where they are feted and invited to speak publicly about their successful mission.Thirty-odd years pass. Stefan is now head of the Mossad. Stefan and Rachel have been married and divorced, and have a daughter who is a notable Israeli journalist. Their daughter writes their memoirs which become an international best-seller.At the same time that their daughter's book comes to print, a Ukrainian journalist announces that he has gotten an exclusive interview with a old man claiming to be the Surgeon of Birkenau. Rachel, Stefan and David's thirty-five year old lie begins to unravel. How they deal with that unraveling and the consequences they face make up the kernel of THE DEBT.I didn't like THE DEBT. I can't appreciate films where the motives and motivations of the characters get twisted into Turkish Taffy by dint of their own stupidity. There's something pathetic about watching intelligent people knowingly sticking their feet into bear traps, and that's what we have here. THE DEBT's biggest failing is the moral relativism of its characters. Dr. Vogel is the only character who seems to have the courage of his convictions, however twisted they may be. What I kept asking myself as THE DEBT played out was why the three agents simply didn't kill Vogel after their first botched extraction attempt. In the end, their lie, made true, would have been a better resolution than the self-imposed unresolvable ethical morass in which they lived their lives.
summary: If there is no such thing as absolute morality, then child abuse is not evil, it just may not be your thing---R.M. Pippert

reviewText: "The Debt" is a well-made, well-acted fantasy that pretends to be a realistic thriller.  I'm sympathetic to the storyline, but I hate to say it, this one is laughably bad.  GREAT ACTING though, and the actual production itself is well done.  But the script is ridiculous, thoroughly lacking in credibility, and in the end, this is an exercise in "fantasy escapism" and nothing more.The story concerns the intertwined lives of three Mossad agents who were on a mission in East Berlin to capture and return to Israel for trial a Dr. Mengele-like Nazi who had been hiding under an assumed identity.  The operation becomes botched, and the doctor gets away.  But the Mossad agents agree to tell their superiors that while they succeeded in capturing the doctor, he escaped although got killed by them in the process of trying to escape, and would not be returned to Israel for trial.  Allegedly, this secret "haunts" these agents for the next 30 years (yeah, right), to the point that it disrupts their lives.  And the rest of the film is how at a late stage in life, two of them attempt to fix the problem.It would have been more credible for the story to be geographically placed on the moon rather than East Berlin.  The idea that a "secret operation" could have been run for an extended period of time by several strangers living in an East Berlin apartment building who go unnoticed and do not attract the attention of the Stasi or police would make anyone who knew anything about the Stasi and the East German police state laugh or cringe--I'm not sure which.  More than probably any place on earth, literally nothing could happen in East Berlin without the Stasi and the State knowing about it--often before it even happened.  There is absolutely zero credibility that an operation of this sort could have taken place, so instantly, this story is a fantasy and nothing  more.There's also likely equally little credibility that any intelligence operatives, let alone Mossad agents, would be "haunted" by a botched operation for the rest of their lives.  Based on what I know (including having known some intelligence operatives even if at the time I knew them I was not aware of that fact), if these people had the sort of psychological makeup that would lead them to being "haunted" like this, they would have never been intelligence agents in the first place.Helen Mirren is, as usual, great.  The acting overall is great.  The production is professional (although I'm getting a little tired of the "realistic" camerawork that leaves the screen image shaking rather than stationary).  But in the end, this movie fails badly, undermined by an utterly preposterous script.
summary: A well made and non-thrilling fantasy/thriller that utterly lacks credibility

reviewText: Full marks for ambition: pitting a crack squad from Israel's controversial secret intelligence agency against a retired Nazi makes for a complicated game of good versus evil in any weather. But when your monster, the "Surgeon of Birkenau" (surgeon? Why not butcher? Or slasher?) is not Josef Mengele but one of the lesser villains in the national socialist pantheon of evil (it is all relative, of course) and the Mossad squad is more conflicted in their mission than usual, there is certainly scope for something genuinely challenging.Much is made of Mossad's questionable methods and, in a pointed piece of irony, it is the Israeli Stephan Gold who dehumanises the Nazi prisoner and not, as convention usually requires, the other way round. This is courageous film making, and I can see John Madden getting flack for it in certain conservative quarters. All the more reason to applaud.So to the set up. Back in the seventies, when everything was grimy and brown, Mossad sent three of its youngsters to East Berlin to kidnap said surgeon, now working as a gynaecologist. Their scheme involves Rachel Singer (Jessica Chastain) feigning pregnancy to get close enough to Old Dr Gardener to validate that he is indeed their target. This presents some genuinely chilling scenarios: over a stilted conversation (during which he seems to suspects a ruse), a lone Jewish woman opens her legs with stirrups to a Nazi torturer and his instruments. It's a memorable, creepy scene, and it is well executed by all concerned.Satisfied that they have the right man, the surgeon is thrillingly apprehended and spirited away in preparation for a bold escape from Communist Berlin and rendition to Israel to stand trial for war crimes.Of course, the Mossad escape plan has as many holes in it as the permanently leaking roof of their safe house. When it is eventually upset - as, of course, it must be - it is by something as unforeseeable as a postal worker stepping outside for a cigarette. The team improvises an escape under a hail of bullets from the East German guards, but are nonetheless now intractably stuck behind the iron curtain with an elderly German doctor for a prisoner.In another courageous move, Dr Vogel turns out not to be much of a monster at all - his first concern is for his wife - but neither has he resiled a great deal from his Nazi views. With these he regales and taunts his captors and, sure enough, the shoots of some stockholm syndrome begin to emerge, particularly as regards young Rachel.You'd be forgiven for drawing a parallel with Silence of the Lambs - John Madden wants you to, I think - but the exchanges between Rachel and Dr Vogel have nothing like the weapons-grade intensity of Hannibal Lecter's interlocutions with Clarice Starling. They might have, had Dr Vogel been more of a Mengele.In the Berlin sequence there are some fine performances from an ensemble cast. A special shout out must go to poor old Marton Csokas - once a fairy in The Lord of the Rings and before that geeky Dr. Leonard on a New Zealand soap opera - who excellently plays Mossad leader Stephan Gold for three quarters of the film, but still hasn't got enough name recognition (or pronounceability, perhaps) to get a significant billing despite being a lead role in the film. Sam Worthington does, on the other hand, most recently having been seen as a tall blue mongrel Avatar, and he steals the show with an intense performance as David Peretz, the most idealistic and personally invested of the agents. Though she'd be a closer resemblance to a young Julianne Moore, Jessica Chastain does well as the young Helen Mirren, despite having to sexually tease both David and Stephan simultaneously in a pair of completely non-sensical relationships.The convoluted set of moral imperatives are further compounded by a series of twists that turn the screenplay into a tourniquet. It is difficult to discuss much more of the plot without spoiling surprises as there are so many, but this is symptomatic of the film's weakness: it tries to do too much everything: there are unnecessary angles, subplots, characters and locations. A bit more gusto with the editor's pen on this peripheral stuff might have given room for a better exploration of the central relationship between Rachel and Dr Vogel, which to me is the heart of the film.The East Berlin action over, we transpose to modern day Tel Aviv, where Madden needs Singer (now Helen Mirren, bearing the scars of the operation, physically and psychologically) to have a rationale for re-engaging in something she's long left behind. The device he chooses doesn't ring awfully true: a daughter conceived during the original operation to Stephan who has grown up and written a book about the raid which, despite it misreporting events entirely, Rachel is nonetheless sponsoring.It isn't clear why Rachel Singer would sanction a book about the botched raid, much less an inaccurate one by her own daughter, other than to paint her character into a corner suitable for the screenplay to develop. Screenplay accordingly does so develop: Mirren is characteristically watchable as Rachel, but the film still loses its way in the final reel (it does this even literally: Mirren is obliged to traipse up to a remote mental hospital in the Ukraine for her final showdown).When it should be building to unbearable proportions the tension dissipates and the film ends on a rather ambiguous down-beat. This may be a product of a director wanting to stay true to his intellectual principles at the expense of the easy thrills of a thriller. If so, I think Madden has taken the wrong option: After thirty years, little enough is still at stake (only egos, really) and too many guns and fight sequences have taken place to carry the notion that this film isn't, at its heart, a good old fashioned spy yarn. Fundamentally it is - and a compelling, tense and watchable one at that, though it will be interesting to see how it compares to the newly filmed Tinker, Tailor, Soldier, Spy.Olly Buxton(Flickfeast)
summary: Challenging thriller which over-reaches and loses impetus in the final reel

His horrifying experiments have left thousands dead in brutal and gory ways. The gang had a plan set in place, and according to a new book written about the ordeal, the mission was completed. And futhermore, that very some 30 years later, thing has the two remaining agents fearing for what happens next in life!I don't want to give too much away, because believe me, the nervousness and suspense I felt throughout the movie is unmatched by any other film I saw this year. Believe me, this film is insanely well written. Matthew Vaughn of Kick-Ass and X-Men First Class fame wrote the script, and boy you can tell he did. His charm and genius are all over the film, in a different fashion than the two mentioned films, but his clever writing style is there. The dialogue is sharp and witty, the turn of events is clever. There's loads of suspense throughout the film. Seriously, not one scene had me feeling calm at all. The film was  high octane, ferociously suspenseful thrill ride that had me on the edge of my seat from the first frame.The film also has a great ability to surprise people, and believe me, this movie is filled to the brim with surprise and intrigue. The film's central twist is especially shocking. Believe me, the movie definitely toys with your expectations and perception of events in pretty much every way possible. But the central twist is especially a shocker, as it completely comes out of nowhere and strikes you blindly. At the screening, you could feel everyone tense up, and especially as the film reaches its shattering climax, the suspense just got more unbearable. However, there is some good Vaughn style humour thrown in there for good measure too.The films' performances are fantastic. Helen Mirren shines as per usual as Rachel, and her young counterpart is not only very pretty but amazingly talented too. Jesper Christensen is amazingly scary as the villain, Vogel, and he does so without any gimmicks. But the real surprise is Sam Worthington as David. Believe me, he really, truly shines here. His portrayal is very convincing, and he manages to prove to the audience that he is not just a pretty face. As well as the film's direction is slick and sharp. madden has a fantastic eye for a shot, and it shows, there are a lot of moments of visual brilliance too, and some shots even look spooky at times.In short, The Debt is the biggest surprise of the year, and a true shiner in a dark age for cinema nowadays. reviewText: Helen Mirren has star billing in THE DEBT, and while her performance is yet another in a long line of noteworthy turns..the real reason to see this film NOW is Jessica Chastain.  Chastain, who garnered significant acclaim for THE TREE OF LIFE and then pretty much stole all her scenes in THE HELP, continues her star-making year with a complex, even riveting performance in THE DEBT.The movie jumps around in time a bit, but is never difficult to follow.  We meet three aging former Mossad agents (Helen Mirren, Tom Wilkenson (her ex-husband, confined to a wheelchair) and Ciaran Hinds.  All three are clearly unhappy and we learn pretty quickly that they are carrying a secret knowledge about the time they spent together 30 years previously in East Berlin.  At that time, they were assigned to capture and bring back to Israel a noted Nazi war criminal (Jesper Christensen).  SOMETHING happened during that time.  Much of the film is an explanation of what that SOMETHING was...and then, how the aged protagonists will deal with the consequences when the pigeons return to roost.When the "secret" is revealed, it's a doozy because we have been set up very nicely.  But WHAT the secret turns out to be is far less important than HOW the secret has seeped into and poisoned almost every aspect of their lives.  This is a low-key espionage thriller that also serves as an interesting exploration of ethics.  At the risk of revealing too much, I won't discuss what those ethics are...but suffice it to say that when over, audiences of THE DEBT will likely spend more time discussing moral dilemmas than they will on the plot.It's a solid plot, with some very tense scenes set in those early days in East Berlin.  Chastain is the young Mirren, a new agent on her first assignment.  She's eager but very nave.  And very vulnerable emotionally to spending so much time living in a truly lousy loft with two handsome but very different men.  Sam Worthington (from AVATAR, and quite effective in this very quiet role) is the young version of Hinds...he's a deeply reserved man who clearly carries deep feelings.  This attracts Chastain, but his reticence pushes her into the arms of the team leader (Marton Csokas), a far more charismatic and forward man...but also vaguely repellant.  The dynamic of these three is very interesting...and becomes much more so when they capture their prey.  This experienced (and very evil) predator smoothly plays the 3 agents not so much against each other, but against their own inner doubts.  The group threatens to unravel.I think I've said all I dare about the substance of THE DEBT.  But I must praise the very good performances all around.  Wilkinson and Worthington are nice in their roles.  Mirren, not surprisingly, is terrific in a very non-glamorous role...and in the movie's final few scenes, she is quite stunning.  Csokas, looking like a young Russell Crowe, is as charismatic as he character requires, and I look forward to this performance launching him into a stronger career.  Christensen is chilling...the role of "old Nazi war criminal" is almost a cliché in films now, but here is seems freshly creepy.  And Chastain is the emotional heart of the film and she hits all her marks.  Her amazing bone structure grabs your attention first, but her subtle performance makes her the focal point of every scene she's in.  She's a star.So, there are many reasons to see THE DEBT.  It's not perfect...some of the modern scenes in Israel have little spark to their staging.  Occasionally the emotions on display teeter on the brink of melodrama.  But it's a very entertaining, thought-provoking film for adult audiences and I highly recommend it.

reviewText: Although this film was very loosely based on the real life kidnapping of Adolph Eichmann in the 1960s, "The Debt" is not set in Argentina, but rather in Israel, Germany, and Ukraine.  It's a Hollywood production-- a big star in Helen Mirren-- and very well directed so the suspense keeps building and shocks, when they come, are really gut-wrenching.  What the film is about is what the Israelis wish they could have done-- found Josef Mengele and dealt summary justice to him.  So in this film, a group of young Mossad agents are out to capture a Nazi war criminal who, like the real-life Mengele, is a former Nazi doctor.  The movie doctor worked at Birkenau, a death camp where medical experiments were conducted using the helpless interned prisoners as guinea pigs.  There was a real Birkenau and medical experiments really were carried out on Jews and other prisoners, as most people who know anything about World War II are aware.The agents in the film are two young men and a young woman.  They find the Nazi war criminal and set about the process of capturing him for return to trial in Israel.  If I give any more of the story away, you won't need to see the film.  The story has a strong psychological subtext so it isn't all blood-and-guts espionage thriller.  Unlike Hollywood espionage pot-boilers like the "Bourne" series, it presents a far more realistic picture of what agents need to do to carry out their mission, and what can go wrong.  And, it isn't a unique film by any means; there have been other such movies about the capture of war criminals, some more factual than others.  But this one is worth seeing because of the splendid performance by Helen Mirren, and the technical perfection of the film itself, including the somber ambiance.  It's gritty and not for the squeamish.  But if you like psychological thrillers and/or espionage thrillers, even though the story is not particularly new, this one is definitely for you.  It's well worth watching.

reviewText: Director John Madden had a smashing back-to-back period in 1997-1998 with "Mrs. Brown" and "Shakespeare in Love", but since then he has been unable to replicate that level of success.  "The Debt", a remake of a 2007 Israeli thriller of the same name, is his best film since that period, and deserves a wider audience than it is likely to find in theatres after more than a year spent in limbo due to the difficulties of its distributor.  Madden and his cast and crew deliver a very solid adult-oriented Cold War thriller.  Spoilers follow.Our story takes place both in East Berlin in 1966 and Israel in 1997 (I would estimate the split to be perhaps 70/30 in the favour of 1966).  It opens with a book launch celebrating the exploits of three Mossad agents in killing a Nazi war criminal: agents Rachel Singer (Helen Mirren), David Peretz (Ciaran Hinds) and Stephan Gold (Tom Wilkinson).  We also see the mission in question, where the trio (played in 1966 by Jessica Chastain, Sam Worthington, and Martin Csokas) are tasked to abduct Dr. Dieter Vogel (Jesper Christensen), the 'surgeon of Birkenau', from East Germany. reviewText: A clever movie, very well acted, and ingeniously structured.  It was based on an Israeli movie of the same name, which I haven't seen but which I assume was similarly structured in the way that the two time periods (1966, 1997) were handled.  One particular success is the way that the different generations of actors are convincing and credible as their younger and older selves.  We can believe that Jessica Chastain grows older to become Helen Mirren, Sam Worthington to become Ciaran Hinds, etc.  and that speaks to the care in the writing of the parts as well as the skills of the actors involved.  The reservation I have concerns the thirty years we don't see: we do see the anguish of the choice that the younger characters make (to tell a lie for the good of Israel is the way that Stefan Gold, the senior Mossad agent, frames the reasons for the lie), but when the three agents are feted as heroes, there is moral discomfort on the parts of the female agent Rachel (Mirren) and David Peretz, the other agent involved (Hinds).  That moral discomfort is heightened when Rachel and Stefan's daughter publishes a book about the 1966 operation that confirms the heroism of the agents and, unbeknownst to Rachel's daughter, cements the lie.  Revelation of the truth would of course discredit the agents and devastate the daughter, whom we see in the opening scenes at her big publication party.There comes a point where it seems that the truth will be revealed and the question is, what to do about it.  I won't give away the later part of the 1997 story except to say that Hinds and Mirren act their moral conflicts and scruples convincingly, but one does wonder how Rachel, Mirren's character, in particular managed the intervening years.  Especially one wonders how she handled the knowledge of her daughter's work on the book.  Divorced by this time from Stefan (who had impregnated her in the course of a one-night bedding in 1966), and as morally scrupulous as she seems to have become, is it credible that she would have let her daughter build her reputation as a writer on what she (Rachel) knows to be a lie?  David, the most morally scrupulous and most troubled of the three, left Mossad and Israel shortly after the events of 1966, and his guilt seems to have led him to have to seek psychiatric help, but we only hear about that on his return in 1997; it's not shown.  Things from Rachel's 1966-1997 life are likewise not shown.  Mirren is a good enough actor to convince us of her 1997 moral discomfort, but it's her success in communicating that that makes us wonder about the intervening years.  For all that, though, this is well worth seeing -- there are elements of suspense and action too that are well handled.

reviewText: *** This review may contain spoilers ***'The Debt' is based on a 2007 Israeli film of the same name. The basic plot is the same: three Mossad agents, two men and a woman, attempt to kidnap a Nazi war criminal in East Berlin in 1965 and ferret him back to Israel for trial.Of course the main idea is taken from the actual abduction of Eichmann in Argentina in 1960. There are two main differences between the actual historical event and what we see here. First of all, and most important, the Mossad operation to abduct Eichmann, albeit extremely difficult, was possible as the agents were operating in a relatively free country (as compared to the countries of the Soviet bloc). To accept the idea that the Mossad would even consider attempting to ferret a Nazi war criminal out of East Germany at the height of the Cold War, that's something I had a hard time believing. Even the Mossad, I believe, would have considered such a plan as 'too risky'.The second principal difference between the Eichmann abduction and the one in 'The Debt', is that the fictional Nazi war criminal the Mossad agents abduct, 'Dieter Vogel', is modeled on the sadistic doctor of Auschwitz, Josef Mengele, and not the banal bureaucrat, Eichmann. Like the Vogel character, Mengele posed as a gynecologist, performing illegal abortions after the war. The real-life Eichmann proves much more interesting than the fictional Vogel, pretty much a standard Nazi film villain. Eichmann, on the other hand, is fascinating since he hardly fits the mold of the typical sadistic Nazi--rather, he resembled the ordinary German you might casually bump into randomly on the street--an individual one would hardly suspect as the chief facilitator of the Final Solution.If you think about it, it didn't take a whole lot of imagination on the screenwriters' part to come up with the main plot, which involves a true-life, successful intelligence operation, turned on its head. 'The Debt' in effect is an Eichmann-like abduction gone bad. There is a historical precedent for a botched Mossad operation--the Lillehammer affair, where the Mossad assassinated the wrong man in their quest to eliminate one of the leaders of the Munich massacre. That's a more likely scenario than the unlikely events depicted here. While the botched escape at the train station hardly seemed true to life, at least it was suspenseful. But when Vogel manages to untie himself and escape the apartment, the entire scenario seemed a little too convenient. Worse is the awkward denouement, where Helen Mirren playing the middle-aged heroine Rachel Singer, travels to Ukraine and ends up getting herself done in by the Nazi antagonist, only to dispatch him at the last second (and in the nick of time).It's not that I disliked the whole idea of Singer paying off her debt to her country--it's just that I couldn't believe an aging, retired Mossad agent, would take it upon herself to 'finish the job' herself. It's good for the movies but even retired Mossad agents realize there are certain protocols involved in various intelligence missions and one doesn't 'go rogue', especially when one is pushing seventy.'The Debt' is generally well-acted but in the end, I just didn't care about the love triangle which forms the basis of a rather tedious sub-plot. There was also a lack of continuity between the actors who were playing the younger roles and the older ones depicted in the present day.Perhaps what the film scenarists were getting at is that actors in organizations such as the Mossad, which is generally thought of as pretty favorable in the west, are also fallible. The protagonist certainly redeems herself in the end by sacrificing her life but do we really care? The absurd romantic angle grows tedious and we never become truly invested in the antagonist, who lacks a back story and is more a caricature, than a fleshed out human being.
summary: Predictable Eichmann-like abduction tale turned on its head

reviewText: Set in 1965 and 2003 "The Debt" develops two parallel stories about Rachel Singer (Jessica Chastian playing the character in the past and Helen Mirren in the present),Stephan Gold (Marton Csokas and Tom Wilkinson ditto) and David Peretz (Sam Worthington and Ciarán Hinds ditto) three Mossad agents tasked with catching a Nazi war criminal Dieter Vogel (Jesper Christiansen)in East Germany that goes horribly wrong. The film has terrific twists and turns that nicely keep viewers guessing and on the edge of their seats; did they grab the right person? Will Vogel's taunting trip them up or will one of them do something rash?The only flaws with the film is that the alternating storylines taking place in past and present tends to dissipate the tension as well as the fact that we really never learn what motivated the characters to become Mossad much less take on this mission (beyond the loss of Rachel's mother during World War II in a concentration camp).The casting is terrific though with each actor doing a nice job of tailoring their performances so they seem as if they are playing the same characters. Aging the actors or using CGI to make them appear older would have distracted and pulled audiences out of the film (or at least me) and casting different actors that resemble each other to play characters 40 years later works for the film.The Blu-ray looks quite nice with a nice, sharp presentation that's free of over processing. The presentation stays true to the theatrical presentation of the film--the greenish, cool tinge for the scenes set in 1965 East Germany adds to the oppressive look set behind the Iron Curtain. Fine detail is remarkably strong throughout in what was reportedly a 2K high def transfer.The lossless DTS audio impressively presents both the action and the quieter scenes that are dialogue driven.The special features include an audio Commentary with John Madden and Producer Kris Thykier where they alternate between giving us insightful observations about shooting the film, the characters and what they wanted to accomplish to merely describing the action.We get three featurettes including a behind-the-scenes look at the making of the film, an interview with Mirren discussing her character and "The Berlin Affair" which focuses on all three characters, their dynamics, etc."The Debt" has some terrific performances and although the structure doesn't always work to the advantage of the film, it's well worth checking out.

reviewText: The Debt (an American remake of a 2007 Israeli film of the same name) is best described as a story on two levels.  On one level, it's a melodramatic espionage thriller that takes places in the 1960's, while on the other, it's a mystery that unfolds thirty years later, one that is centered around the events of the original espionage mission.  The film cuts back and forth between these two story lines, with a different trio of actors portraying the three main characters in each story line.In 1966, a trio of Israeli Mossad agents - Rachel Singer (Jessica Chastain), David Peretz (Sam Worthington) and Stefan Gold (Marton Csokas) - are sent behind the Iron Curtain in East Berlin to kidnap an escaped Nazi war criminal, Dieter Vogel (Jesper Christiansen), the infamous "Surgeon of Birkenau".  The mission goes awry when, after successfully capturing Vogel, the plan to smuggle him out of East Berlin is disrupted and they are forced to go into hiding while they try to make other arrangements.  It is while he is being held prisoner that Vogel overpowers Rachel and almost escapes, leaving her face grievously scarred in the process.  But Rachel manages to shoot Vogel before he gets away, killing him, and the trio return to Israel as heroes and their mission becomes a Mossad legend.  Later, Rachel and Stefan marry, for reasons that are quite frankly never made clear and end up having a daughter, and David decides to leave.But in the current day (1997) story line, things are more complicated.  Rachel (Helen Mirren) is being honored at a publication party for her daughter Sarah (Romi Aboulafia) who has written a book about her parents' legendary mission.  Already visibly uncomfortable when asked to read a key passage from the book, Rachel becomes even more displeased when Stefan (Tom Wilkinson), now in a wheelchair and from whom she is completely estranged, shows up at the party, a situation clearly set up by Sarah who had told her mother than he wouldn't be there.  At the same time, David (Ciaran Hinds) has also resurfaced, clearly troubled. And we begin to learn that there are cracks in the legend, and ultimately, that the legend is nothing but a self-serving lie that all three have lived with for the last thirty years.I will acknowledge that my reaction to The Debt is in the minority as it was garnered a fair amount of critical praise, but that said, I found myself ultimately disappointed.  I cannot fault the performances of the stellar cast, nor can I really fault the director, John Madden, beyond the pacing problem.  I would probably lay the blame for my overall reaction with the script (the one done for the remake) which was written by Matthew Vaughn and Jane Goldman.  I have not seen the original Israeli film on which it was based, but in reading the plot summary it appears that some substantial changes were made for this version and that, from what some reviewers say, the original was better.  But that aside, for me the problem with The Debt lies in the fact that it requires some considerable suspensions of disbelief, and that, quite frankly, most of the characters are not particularly likeable or sympathetic.  Stefan is a manipulative, self-centered ladder-climber whose only concerns are his ambitions and his career.  And both Rachel and David are easily manipulated, in addition to forever vacillating in their feelings towards each other, towards Stefan, and inexplicably at times, towards Vogel.  And in their older selves, they have not grown wiser so much as simply worse.The pacing in the beginning is also something of a problem and I actually found myself falling asleep before things finally picked up with the abduction of Vogel. But even when things did pick up, I found myself not really liking it all that much. The characters were so flawed as individuals - and even more flawed as a team - it was difficult to accept the initial premise.  I wouldn't have sent that crew around the corner to pick up a pack of gum, let alone behind the Iron Curtain to kidnap an escaped Nazi.  And the fact that they weren't very sympathetic as individuals made the tepidly melodramatic love triangle subplot more tedious than anything else. I also found it difficult to believe that Vogel would've left Rachel alive before fleeing the apartment.  Or that any competent intelligence officer would've simply accepted their story when they got back.It also says something when the only halfway interesting scenes are the ones with the Nazi doctor, even when written as it is in the The Debt as something of a cliche. For that I'd have to credit the actor - Jesper Christensen - who manages to at least make his repellant doctor fascinating to watch - much like a particularly vicious caged rat - even if you've seen the basic character in countless movies before and the dialogue is just variations on the same old theme.  That Christensen's Vogel, even with the clichés, was about the only thing in The Debt worth seeing, says a lot about the rest of the film.  As does the fact that even having Vogel for contrast does not make the ostensible heroes particularly sympathetic.Again, I recognize that my opinion is a minority one.  If you read a review by someone you trust and they say see it, then go ahead.  For myself though, I'd say The Debt is okay if you don't go in expecting much and if you can wade through the ramped-up self-inflicted angst the main characters wallow in for most of the movie.
summary: A great cast but otherwise disappointing
